venue.name: The Florence & Chafetz Hillel House at Boston University

item.description:
This two-part program takes place at 3:30 (webcast symposium) and 5:30 (live colloquium/reception). So, you can participate online even if you aren't able to make it to BU during the workday!

* * *

Special for Valentineâ€™s Day, the Department of Anthropology at BU has organized a symposium that brings together eight experts on human biology. Their discussion will spotlight the defects and deficiencies of the human body, those clumsy compromises in the construction of our teeth, feet, backs, bottoms, and birthings that reflect our history as jury-rigged, made-over apes. Taking their cue from Wilton Krogman's 1951 classic "The Scars of Human Evolution," the symposium participants will demonstrate and discuss how and how far the human body fails by the standards of intelligent design.

Speakers:

  • Rachel Caspari, Central Michigan University
  • Jeremy DeSilva, Boston University
  • Karen Rosenberg, University of Delaware
  • Bruce Latimer, Case Western Reserve University
  • Alan Mann, Princeton University
  • William Leonard, Northwestern University
  • Milford Wolpoff, University of Michigan
  • Matt Cartmill, Boston University

Read their online statements here and watch the six-person webcast at 3:30 at http://www.bu.edu/anthrop/dialogues/unintelligentdesign/webcast/.

All persons are also welcome to attend the free public colloquium at 5:30 in BU's Hillel House, where you can meet the speakers and put questions to them in person. A reception and refreshments will follow.
item.name: BU Anthropology Webcast & Colloquium: "Unintelligent Design"
